Description: Rim sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; part of palmette, rosette and lotus flower in added white outline with added red centres; below, white band above red band; top of rim glazed; exterior: broken maeander frieze between pairs of bands at rim; below, painted decoration consisting of upper part of bearded man in chiton and himation, to right, holding up a lotus flower in his left hand; added red in hair and on chiton.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds of the Grand Style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy. It ought to be pointed out, however, that there is no evidence for filling ornament on this sherd. The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.114.3. The rim pattern is similar to that found on British Museum 1888,0601.476.c.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 110, p. 272, no. 704, pl. I, 92)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0806) (phase 2)
